definition: to fall over each other in their eagerness to...
to strive for/to vie for/to argue or debate/deficient or lacking (dialect)/how or what (literary)
each other/one another/mutually/fret on the neck of a pipa 琵琶[pi2 pa5] (a fret on the soundboard is called a 品[pin3])
surname Xiang
appearance/portrait/picture/government minister/(physics) phase/(literary) to appraise (esp. by scrutinizing physical features)/to read sb's fortune (by physiognomy, palmistry etc)

sentences.english: Does north and south Han scramble for making space trash , the nobody tube?
sentences.chinese: 南北韩争相制造太空垃圾，没人管管？

sentences.english: Already, he says, people are flocking to the new, efficient products.
sentences.chinese: 他说，人们已经争相购买新的节能产品了。

sentences.english: A report by Jiangxi Economic and Trade Department also shows the trend of an emulative inrushing of foreign investment.
sentences.chinese: 江西省经贸厅一份报告也显示了外资争相涌入的趋势。

sentences.english: At meal times the odour of sauerkraut vies with that of garlic.
sentences.chinese: 用饭的时候，德国泡菜味和大蒜味争相散发。

sentences.english: If the Sitka plan succeeds, other water-rich cities may soon follow.
sentences.chinese: 如果西特卡的计划成功，其他的多水城市会争相效仿。

sentences.english: Siblings become enemies, fighting over assets that are left.
sentences.chinese: 所遗家产，成为兄弟反目，争相抢夺。

sentences.english: Meanwhile operators are scrambling to catch up.
sentences.chinese: 与此同时经营商们争相赶上。

sentences.english: Since then, people rushed to convert to expand the ethos, buddhist apart.
sentences.chinese: 此后，人们争相皈依，信佛的风气便扩大开来。

sentences.english: But when a ten-year married man looks happy, we wonder why.
sentences.chinese: 十年婚男若露喜，大家争相会猜谜。

sentences.english: When Lai Gemi is released, people scramble to his house to see him.
sentences.chinese: 当莱格米被释放后，人们争相前往他的住所去看望他。

sentences.english: Now, there seems to be a competition to punish him.
sentences.chinese: 而现在呢，似乎所有人都在争相惩治被告。

definition: competitive/eagerly/to vie
to compete to be first/to contest first place
striving to be first and fearing to be last (idiom); outdoing one another
one after another/in succession/one by one/continuously/diverse/in profusion/numerous and confused/pell-mell
index (loanword)
to rush like ducks (idiom); the mob scrabbles madly for sth unobtainable/an unruly crowd on a wild goose chase
to respond instantly/to act at once on hearing the news
to come thick and fast (idiom)
numerous
a craze/a popular wave/a hit with the public
see 仿傚|仿效[fang3 xiao4]
to chase after (a popular person or item)/to pursue/popularity
delicious cakes/popular person/sth that is in high demand
to compete/to fight for/to rush to purchase
continuously; in an endless stream (idiom)
large quantities of
